title: Global Special Humanitarian visa
summary: This page provides detailed information about the Subclass 202 Global Special Humanitarian visa, which allows eligible individuals facing human rights abuses to resettle permanently in Australia. It explains eligibility, costs, processing priorities, obligations, family inclusion rules, and the application process (including mandatory use of ImmiAccount from 1 July 2025).

structured_data.description: A permanent visa for people facing substantial human rights violations and who have a connection to Australia or are joining an immediate family member.

from_1_july_2025_changes.process: Proposer must complete the proposal first and provide the transaction reference number (TRN). Applicant must use the TRN within 60 days to apply in ImmiAccount.

key_features: Propose certain family members for permanent residence
Travel to and from Australia for 5 years
If eligible, become an Australian citizen
Attend free English classes through the Adult Migrant English Program

general_requirements: Must enter Australia by the date on the visa
You and accompanying family must obey Australian laws

how_long_you_can_stay.details: You become a permanent resident on the day you enter Australia on this visa.

allowed_family_members: Other dependent relatives (parent, grandparent, sibling, grandchild, aunt, uncle, niece, nephew, cousin)
requirements: Family members who apply must meet health and character requirements
Non-migrating family members may need to meet health requirements
All family members must be declared
Undeclared family members may not be eligible for later humanitarian sponsorship

cost.exception: A fee applies if proposed under the Community Support Program by an Approved Proposing Organisation

structured_data.apply_from: You must be outside Australia and outside your country of origin.

important_notes: More applications are received each year than available places
processing_can_be_delayed_if: Documents are missing or additional information is required

priority_groups.note: SHP applications are processed in order of priority group.

groups.description: Proposer is an immediate family member who holds or held a Protection or Resolution of Status visa or a Class XB visa, and the applicant meets split-family criteria.
Proposer is a close family member and does not hold a Protection or Resolution of Status visa.
Proposer is an extended family member and does not hold a Protection or Resolution of Status visa.
Proposer is a distant relative, friend, or community organisation and does not hold a Protection or Resolution of Status visa.
Proposer holds a Protection or Resolution of Status visa.

split_family_criteria: Proposer was an immediate family member when they were granted their visa
Relationship was declared before their visa grant
Visa application is proposed within 5 years of the proposer’s visa grant
proposer_restrictions: Unauthorised maritime arrivals (UMA) who arrived on or after 13 August 2012 cannot propose family members
additional_policy_priorities: Applicants proposed by an immediate family member holding a Class XB visa
Members of minority groups such as women and girls, ethnic minorities, LGBTQI+, referred by UNHCR or proposed by family in Australia

your_obligations: Enter Australia by the initial arrival date listed on the visa grant letter
Comply with any signed health undertaking

assisted_passage.program_purpose: Supports the delivery of Australia’s Offshore Humanitarian Program with health screening and travel assistance.
services: Assist with travel to Australia after visa grant
assisted_passage.additional_travel_support: Assistance may also be available through the International Organization for Migration (IOM) under the prepaid migration travel program.
